#1

For the last week or so, the models have been showing a spell of heat starting in mid September, possibly lasting for a week. A long fetch North Westerly air stream will be pumping a very warm and dry air mass from the interior of the continent over the State. The Westerly is not that strong, so sea breezes will moderate conditions on the coastal fringe. Away from the coast, September heat records might be at risk. Over Sydney, 850 temps are predicted to be as high as 18-19° on the 19th, consistent with mid 30s maxima in fine conditions.

A remarkable aspect of this event is its duration. Five days seems to be locked in, but it may be longer.

Unlike most of the last couple of years, NW’ers are no longer delivering cloud bands. Skies are expected to be fairly clear, long-range forecasts show little or no rain for the next couple of weeks. Fire danger will likely be high or very high over wide areas of the State.

Here are the current BOM forecasts, September 15-19:

Newcastle: 27, 31, 29, 29, 31

Maitland: 29, 32, 32, 31, 33

Sydney: 25, 30, 28, 27, 30

Penrith: 31, 34, 33, 33, 34

Albion Park: 28, 31, 29 28, 31

#2

GFS - MOS still going for near 40 on Monday the 18th of September - appears to be at the airport site.

As I've said previously, I don't actually mind a bit of heat. We have had a few quite summers so we are somewhat due for hot conditions. Where I have some concerns is the early nature of the heat, its duration, and the fact that we have no significant rain on the horizon.

If this was November/December and we had 4-5 days of 30-35+ followed by a strong southerly with rain for a few days / and or some thunderstorms, I would love it. Instead it's September, and there's no rain. 10 day multi model forecast shows 4 fifths of bugger all rain

Why can't we just have some normal weather please? If it's not record rain, it's record heat and dry.

#3

Sydney Airport’s September record high is 35.6°, attained 29/9/2000. This was during the Sydney Olympics in another warm September. The Airport’s October record is 39.1° (13/10/2004).

So 39° at the Airport before the Equinox (4:50 pm 23 September) would be quite remarkable.

P.S. GFS shows 850 temps over Sydney in the afternoon of next Tuesday 19th at about 19°, consistent with a max of maybe 35-37° under clear skies in the absence of a sea breeze. BOM forecasts for Tuesday for the Sydney area are ~ 29-34°.

We’ll see how it goes.

No actual heat in Sydney’s East today, where OH didn’t even make to 24°, 2° short of its forecast. In the Sydney Basin, it reached 30° West from about Bankstown and Parramatta.

It looks like a five day heat event, Saturday to Wednesday, followed by a return to seasonal temperatures, with showers likely over the weekend after this one.

Here are the current Sydney forecast maxima, 16th -20th:

Sydney OH: 32, 30, 30, 32, 32

Parramatta: 33, 31, 33, 34, 34

Penrith: 34, 33, 36, 35, 35.

That is an extraordinary burst of heat for this time of year.

OH might be overcooked, I think the sea-breeze will start early on some days against a weak Westerly stream. However, not the two inland sites. September records may be at risk.

The forecasts for Newcastle and the Central Coast are about the same, Wollongong a bit cooler.

Above is a fire weather risk animation based on the NFDRD Burning Index for Tuesday to Thursday where the blackish red areas typically translate to significantly elevated fire weather.

Isolated dry lightning and that change will be additional things to watch out for.

Also above is the latest from the ensemble median of the bias-corrected version of NAEFS re the highest daily max temps it achieves at any stage within the next 6 day period.

But because of its somewhat coarse 0.5 degree resolution, there'll be locally hotter or cooler temps than what's shown e.g. Sydney Airport's max so far today is 34.7C

And a couple of animations of the min and max temps from the EC ensemble's extreme forecast index (not anomalies). Values above +0.9 often correspond in the real world to temps starting to get close to record warm values for this part of the month, and values closer to +1 typically equate to heat records being tied or broken.

Sharp latitudinal gradient with the heat today. Albury, despite being forecast to 29 °C, is struggling past 25 °C with the arrival of the southerly - I bet its residents were cheerful for it. Meanwhile, Wagga is now pushing upward of 31 °C; and Tumbarumba generally ranging in maxes between 25 and 26 °C, with one station reading 27.5 °C (the post office might be around 27 °C).

Tomorrow's forecast calls for a potentially record-breaking 28 °C in Tumba (27.8 °C from Sep 1965 is the current record). Of course, the Bureau were right and this heat might actually end up worse than forecast because, you know, it's 2023 doing 2023 things. This hot house year couldn't end sooner.

Heatwave Warning​

IDN21013

Heatwave Warning For New South Wales​

Issued at 01:56pm EST on Monday 18 September 2023

Valid for Monday 18 September 2023 to Wednesday 20 September 2023​

Severe Heatwave Warning for: Illawarra and South Coast Districts

Heatwave Situation for 3 days starting Saturday 16th September 2023

Heatwave Situation for 3 days starting Sunday 17th September 2023

Heatwave Situation for 3 days starting Monday 18th September 2023

Heatwave Situation for 3 days starting Tuesday 19th September 2023

Safety Advice​

Severe heatwaves can be dangerous for many people, especially older people, babies, children, pregnant and breastfeeding women, people with medical conditions and people who are unwell.

Seek a place to keep cool, such as your home, a library, community centre or shopping centre.

Close your windows and draw blinds, curtains or awnings early in the day to keep the heat out of your home.

If available, use fans or air-conditioners to keep cool.

For information on staying safe during a heatwave go to the NSW Department of Health web page.

Weather Situation​

Maximum temperatures reaching the low to mid-thirties with overnight minimum temperatures in the mid to high teens. These temperatures are around ten to fifteen degrees above average and persist for an unusually prolonged period for this time of year. Severe heatwave conditions will ease in the wake of a cold front from late Wednesday.

Locations likely to be impacted include Batemans Bay and Wollongong.

The next heatwave warning will be issued by 3:00pm EST on Tuesday 19 September 2023
